Culture and Commuinications Midterm Essays

2021/08/03

Essay One

Gregory Bateson’s theory of natural systems as abstracting systems, with conscious purpose as a kind of extreme and potentially dangerous extension of the abstracting process.

General Theory

Gregory Bateson believed that ecosystems and human biology don’t exist on the event level, it’s only through viewing on a more abstract level do we see the circuits that keep it balanced and functioning. He observed that “creatures and plants live together in a combination of competition and mutual dependency”Gregory Bateson, Mind and Nature: A Necessary Unity (New York: Dutton, 1979), 438.. Each component of this biological machinery functions as gauges and fail-safes. These elements remain invisible when viewed at the physical/sensorial level.

This system functions primarily on both levels two and four of Korzybski’s abstraction model It lives within level two as an autonomous process similar to digestion or blood pumping through a living creature. Each part of this system is oblivious of the role it plays within the larger whole. Without the existence of every component, it begins to falter. Only through bringing this system into the verbal fourth level are we able to perceive and put into actual terms the full processes happening directly in front of us. Having pulled this ecosystem into a fourth-level framework we are able to see what Bateson is trying to show us in this paper. He wants the reader to realize that “in a balanced ecological system whose underpinnings are of this nature, it is very clear that any monkeying with the system is likely to disrupt the equilibrium”Bateson, Mind and Nature, 438..

He uses the example of the “balance of nature” to illustrate this point. The balance of nature is a term used to describe the interconnectedness of all living things. Bateson argues that this balance is not a conscious act but a natural one. It is only through abstracting the system that we are able to see the balance of nature in action.

The Flaws

The ability to abstract acts as a double-edged blade, with both the success and downfall of humans living in said ecosystems hinged on how humanity applies it. His largest concern was that humanity through its hubris would latch onto conscious purpose and not realize the harms of it. Bateson draws attention to the fact that “conscious purpose is now empowered to upset the balance of the body”Bateson, Mind and Nature, 441..

The body in this instance refers to the ecological system we live in. “common-sense” of consciousness, which leads to greed and irrational decisionsBateson, Mind and Nature, 442.. “common-sense” of consciousness, which leads to greed and irrational decisionsBateson, Mind and Nature, 442..

This is so dangerous as conscious purpose allows humans to sever their connection to the ecosystems they inhabit. Bateson uses an interpretation of the story of Adam and Eve to exhibit this. He states “[Adam] still does not see himself as part of the system in which the mess exists, and he either blames the rest of the system or he blames himself”Bateson, Mind and Nature, 443..

Conscious purpose acts as a pane of frosted glass through which humans are unable to see the unintended results of their actions. Humans end up viewing themselves in a distorted manner and act as if they exist above and are removed from the systems they inhabit. This methodology of thinking is dangerous and the cause of these systems’ downfall. This will lead to a deterioration as Bateson puts it “Some plants will become a weed, some creatures will be exterminated, and the system [...] is likely to fall to pieces”Bateson, Mind and Nature, 438.. As plants move towards weed and animals become either extinct or pests it creates a less hospitable environment for the elements that remain. The solution is complex and simple, but it begins with humanity realizing the problem is systemic in natureBateson, Mind and Nature, 444.. Next, Bateson says that the problem must then be tackled on an individual scale through humility. It is once we combat the arrogance of conscious purpose that humans will be able to tackle the damage we have already doneBateson, Mind and Nature, 446..

Essay 2

How is six-week-old Joey’s experience is different from ours, and where do we find the roots of the ability to sense Structure and to Differentiate in the midst of the Weatherscape The Weatherscape is Daniel Stern’s concept describing an infant’s early experience where they are fully immersed in sensory and emotional input, without a sense of separation between themselves and the world around them.

The Difference

The Weatherscape can best be related to adults as experiencing a flow state while doing something they enjoy. It is a state where the person within it has full involvement and feels a direct connectedness to the outside world. When a baby first comes into the world there is no distinct separation between where they end and the world begins. Stern phrases this lack of separation as “there is no you to stand outside the weather and watch it happen” Daniel Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," in The Interpersonal World of the Infant (New York: Basic Books, 1985), 14.. As a baby, Joey is forced to exist within all the storms and calms of the world around him. Elaborating on this further, “Joey experiences objects and events mainly in terms of feelings they evoke in him” Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 13.. Joey lives within the Weatherscape which is a continuous existence at the lowest level of abstraction. Joey does not care or understand at this point anything further than the physical and sensory level. All of his brain is grappling with the large influx of new information as “all his senses are focused on each one, and he lives each intensely” Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 15.. For adults a flow state would function as a temporary pseudo Weatherscape.

Exiting the Weatherscape

Exiting of the Weatherscape happens as babies start to grasp the concept of object permanence. Before this gradual exit, a game of peekaboo captivates as new stimuli appear out of supposed thin air before disappearing again. As this game loses interest the outside world starts to bleed less into the inside world of baby Joey’s mind. This clear division is a product of lived experience and recall of past memories. Stern points this out when talking about Joey's experience regarding the bars on Joey's crib. Joey begins to notice the first bar primes him to notice the second” Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 26.. Without this the afterglow begins to strengthen Joey will start his exit of the Weatherscape. Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 27., rather than the memories we as adults experience. Once the afterglow begins to strengthen Joey will start his exit of the Weatherscape.

Stern earlier provides an expansion and progression of this skill by bringing up the game Botticelli Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 24.. This game requires adults to translate the qualities of an experience and attribute it to a specific person Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 25.. Babies are born already able to play as their nervous systems are wired to work this way although prior experience definitely helps Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 25.. A blindfolded baby after being breastfed will exhibit favouritism towards the nipple they had fed upon when later being presented two to choose between by merely on sight Stern, "The World of Feelings: Baby Joey at Six Weeks," 25.. This decision-making clearly shows the translational skills mentioned above.
